Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: IPY: Arctic System Reanalysis
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will develop an Arctic System Reanalysis (ASR). The ASR, which can be viewed as a blend of modeling and observations, will provide a high resolution description in space (20 km) and time (3 h) of the atmosphere-sea ice-land surface system of the Arctic. The ASR will ingest historical data streams along with measurements of the physical components of the Arctic Observing Network being developed as part of the IPY. Gridded fields from the ASR, such as temperature, radiation and winds, will also serve as drivers for coupled ice-ocean, land surface and other models, and will offer a focal point for coordinated model inter-comparison efforts. The ASR will permit reconstructions of the Arctic system's state, thereby serving as a state-of-the-art synthesis tool for assessing Arctic climate variability and monitoring Arctic change. The ASR will also shape the legacy observing network of the IPY by providing a vehicle for observing system sensitivity studies. The first generation ASR as outlined here will span the years 2000-2010.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Arctic System Reanalysis (ASR) is a multi-institutional interdisciplinary effort to provide a high-resolution description of the Arctic's atmosphere-sea ice-land system by assimilating a diverse suite of observations into a regional model.  The ASR output includes gridded fields of temperature, radiation, winds and numerous other variables at high spatial (~15 km) and temporal (3 h) resolution.  The ASR provides detailed reconstructions of the Arctic system's state, and represents a key synthesis tool for assessing and monitoring variability and change in the Arctic system. ASR fields also serve as drivers for coupled ice-ocean and other models, and provide a focal point for coordinated model inter-comparison efforts. The ASR responds directly to needs identified in the Implementation Plan for the Study of Environmental Arctic Change (SEARCH). The widespread applications of existing global atmospheric reanalyses demonstrate the high impact that can be expected on Arctic research. The ASR is built upon lessons learned from past reanalyses by optimizing model physics and parameterizations to Arctic conditions, as well as by optimizing methods of data assimilation.

The ASR is based on an Arctic optimized version of the Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) modeling and data assimilation system.  Arctic enhancements are channeled through the National Center for Atmospheric Research for release to the community.  Easy access to and effective visualization of ASR output is high priority; tools developed for the NCEP/NCAR reanalysis by the NOAA Earth Systems Research Laboratory Physical Sciences Division provide guiding principles. ASR output is estimated as about 5 TB per year. This raw output will be processed to ~10% of this volume for distribution, following the general approach of the NCEP North American Regional Reanalysis. The system-oriented approach required for the ASR demands collaboration between the Arctic terrestrial, sea ice, ocean and atmospheric communities. The reanalysis capitalizes on prior investment in large Arctic field programs (e.g., SHEBA, LAII/ATLAS, ARM) that provide information for testing improved high-latitude physics and parameterizations. The first generation ASR spans the years 2000-2012. Comparison between ASR with ERA-Interim global reanalysis indicates ASR has lower biases, lower RMS, and higher correlations than ERA-Interim for 10 m wind speed, 2 m temperature, 2 m dew point, and surface pressure. The pattern and amount of annual precipitation from ASR and ERA-Interim are similar for each of years 2000-2009, except that ASR gives higher precipitation amounts in regions of complex terrain. These results indicate the value of high-resolution ASR for science applications.
